5 
The following <s>table of<\s> Measurements of Animals killed by 
Lieut. M<sup>c<\sup>Clintock on Melville Island, taken from p 87 of 
the Zoology of H.M.S. Herald enable<s>s<\s> us to realize the size of the 
animal. They are taken in inches & tenths. The weight of the Males 
killed on that island exceeded 700 pounds, of which 400 was meat, "and 
they stood 10[half] hands high at the withers or 42 inches". 
Musk Musk Musk Musk 
Bull Cow Cow Cow 
From Horns to the root of tail 86.0 70.5 64.0 62.0 
From the fore <s>of<\s> hoof to the top of the shoulder 57.0 55.0 - 49.5 
From the hind hoof to the top of the rump 51.0 - - - 
Length of tail 2.0 
Length of one horn 27.0 24.0 - 19.0 
From the tip of one horn to that of the other 32.0 27.3  27.5. 
In this brief r[e acute]sume of the external characters of Ovibos 
the truth of M. de Blainville's views as to its place in 
the scale between Ovis <s>and Capra<\s>  on the one hand and 
Bos on the other is most amply proved. In addition 
to the absence of a muffle and of a dewlap on which his 
classification is principally based, the hairiness of its 
nostrils, the shortness of its tail, the want of symmetry 
in its hoofs, differentiate it from all the Oxen, Bisons 
and Buffaloes, and especially from Bubalus Caffir, which 
it resembles superficially, in the large size and downward 
direction of the horns and the close approximation of their 
bases in the adult males. In these points also it has a 
still closer resemblance to the Gnu or Wildebeest of the 
Cape, as well as in the long hair on its chin, and neck, and 
the e<s>r<\s>rect hair between its shoulders while its smallness 
of ear shortness of tail and want of symmetry in its 
hoofs are among the differences.
